sub_title: Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries
summary:
Summary: 
A driven researcher with a track record of developing materials for energy systems (Lithium, Li-ion, Sodium & Sulfur based batteries, thermo-electrochemical cell) for 9+ years.

Expertise: 
Metallic Lithium thin-film/3D anodes, Li-ion metal oxide/phosphate cathodes synthesis, sulfur/sulfide redox chemistry, molten salt - ceramic oxide composite electrolytes, solid-state electrolyte, and bring together materials characterizations.

Knew-how: 
Interpreting lab-scale findings to analyze & solve challenges in industrial prototypes, forming a balanced academic-industrial alliance and quickly adaptable to new situations & challenges. 

Job-related skills: 
Research independence, multidisciplinary team leadership, working on concurrent projects, working in a consortium to acquire additional grants, and project management.

Long-term goal: 
Develop skills in a variety of energy systems and endeavor to realize their practicality.

projects: [{'title': 'NaSTOR-ionic-liquid-based novel sodium based battery technology for ultra low cost electricity storage (NaSTOR-II)', 'date': {'start': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'This intermediate temperature sodium-sulfur batteries operatable between 150 - 200 °C, uses the molten salts solvated sulfur mixture as catholyte. Research is in progress to exploring the catholyte transport properties to optimize the recipe, and materials for cell components to demonstrate this high voltage battery.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sathiyaraj', 'last_name': 'Kandhasamy, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries'}]}, {'title': 'NaSTOR residential energy system storage prototype (NaSTOR prototype)', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'Established an intermediate temperature NaS battery with a tubular Na-β″ alumina solid-state electrolyte and for the first time operated the system at a low temperature of 125 - 150 °C. Here the catholyte is a mixture of organic solvent (TEGDME), solvated S, and Na2S, with/without other co-salts and co-solvents. Catholyte properties, cell design, and operating protocols are accessed to improve the cell performance. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sathiyaraj', 'last_name': 'Kandhasamy, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries'}]}, {'title': 'Molten carbonate electrolyte based thermocells for high temperature waste heat recovery', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': 'Industrial processes for the production of metals and alloys by metallurgical and electrochemical methods generate a lot of waste heat due to irreversible losses. This waste heat could be used as a power source to produce electricity. An inexpensive molten carbonate electrolyte based thermocell demonstrated the possibility to use this waste heat as a power source. It shows the advantage to harvest industrial waste heat at high temperatures and utilize the available CO\xad\xad2 rich off-gases from metal producing industries.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sathiyaraj', 'last_name': 'Kandhasamy, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries'}]}, {'title': 'Multi-cation doped (LiMn1/3Ni1/3Co1/3PO4) cathodes for aqueous rechargeable battery ', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'description': 'Olivine-phosphate LiCo1/3Mn1/3Ni1/3PO4, synthesized via conventional solid state as well as by modified wet chemical synthesis routes (sol–gel and combustion) are reported as a cathode material for aqueous rechargeable batteries. A range of chelating agents like a weak organic acid (Citric acid - CA),\nemulsifier (Triethanolamine - TEA) and non-ionic surfactant (Polyvinylpyrrolidone - PVP) are used in\nwet chemical synthesis. The olivine cathodes are investigated further by fabricated rechargeable batteries with  Zn anode and aqueous LiOH as electrolyte. In addition, XRD, SEM, TEM, FTIR and XPS techniques are used to understand the physical characteristics of as-prepared, as well as post, cycled cathodes.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sathiyaraj', 'last_name': 'Kandhasamy, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries'}]}, {'title': 'Fabricatication of bio-templates for biosensor by using Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) anodic oxidation', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2010}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}}, 'description': 'A device has been fabricated to perform large area local oxidation with copper wire (thickness 7 μm) as cathode probe. Ability of this device was studied, by silicon oxide (SiO2) dots fabrication on silicon (Si) surface and patterning of model microorganism. This device shows possibilities of overcoming the inherent limitations of large area local oxidation by AFM.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sathiyaraj', 'last_name': 'Kandhasamy, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries'}]}, {'title': 'Synthesis of Nanostructured LiCoO2 [Layered] and LiMn2O4 [Spinel] Cathodes for Lithium Batteries', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2009}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2010}}, 'description': 'LiCoO2 and LiMn2O4 compounds were synthesized using two different methods, viz., low-temperature-aided hydrothermal and high-temperature-assisted co-precipitation method. Keeping the reaction parameters such as type of precursors chosen and the medium of reaction as same for both the hydrothermal and co-precipitation methods, the effect of temperature in producing LiCoO2 and LiMn2O4 with varying physical as well as electrochemical properties has been studied. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sathiyaraj', 'last_name': 'Kandhasamy, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries'}]}, {'title': 'Laser surface modification on AISI 316L SS coated with SiC-Zr-Ti', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}}, 'description': None, 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sathiyaraj', 'last_name': 'Kandhasamy, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Research Scientist - Team Lead                                                                             | Materials & Electrochemistry | 3D/Thin-Film Batteries'}]}]

• Leading a multidisciplinary team for developments at low TRL, working with abstract concepts & uncertainties, it involves initiating, designing, executing, and validating new and established methods/processes.

• Reviewing authoritative publications & patents, fronting data collection and consequent interpretation, ultimately for key IP creation. 
• Combining analytical and quick-thinking abilities to balance research and timelines while pushing the boundary to maximize benefits and reduce risks in attaining the goals.
• Defining a timeline and putting it into action, delegating and managing the daily activities of the internal and external team for accomplishing the set goals.
